text:
As I understand it:
• Forward-mode is about finding the fastest ways to get any column of a Jacobian
• Reverse-mode is about finding the fastest way to get any row of a Jacobian
• Mixed-Mode is about find the fastest way to get the whole Jacobian
• Cross country is about finding the fastest way to give any given *cell* of a Jacobian, i.e. 1 particular partial derivative.
*But I could be totally wrong*

text: I thought it was basically matrix chain multiplication, ie carefully choose the order you compose your linear operators, where left-to-right is forward mode, right-to-left is reverse, and anything else is “cross-country”. I might have misunderstood something though..

text: I agree, but the common matrix chain analogy can also be misleading in terms of complexity. Optimal association order of dense matrices is solvable in O(n log n). In AD, all intermediate Jacobians have structure and finding the optimal accumulation order (min number of FLOPS) is NP-hard.

text: IIUC, if we have want only a few specific entries (i,j) of the Jacobian (that are not necess. within same rows or columns), then worst-case we could do 1 Forward-mode pass per entry. To improve upon this, we might try to either share computation between entries, or don't evaluate the full linearized graph for each entry (but only some relevant subgraph / sum over paths from input i to output j).
